lines.text: I came to collect on that favor you owe me.
You owe *her* a favor?
That's worse than dog breath!
Very funny!
My aunt's alone with two little boys. I gotta go help her out. I'm a ButterCreamer, right?
Yeah!
You know it!

Besides, it's the closest I may ever get to having a real mom. And she does make spaghetti with ketchup. Now, in my last official act as President, I would like to nominate Scott to be President of the ButterCreamers in my absence.
Why do you want to nominate me?
All in favor say aye?
Aye!
Hey, Aunt Maria.
Well, hey, Pete. How'd you do in school today?
Fantastic. Got an A on the old history report.
Pete, that's great. You know, if your parents were alive, they'd be so proud of you. Oh, you got a letter from Scott today. He's your friend, right?
Yeah, he's the best.
Hey, Mom, any mail for me?
No, nothing from Pete. Sorry, Scott.
Do you know what this is? It's a letter from your school. You've been expelled. It says you broke into another kid's locker!
One of the other gangs set me up.
Ever since you were arrested, you've been blaming other people.
I didn't do anything wrong this time.
Well, what you did do was pick the wrong friends, and ever since then you've been getting into trouble!
I'll stop hanging out with them.
You've told me that before. I asked you here because I thought you'd be a good example for my children. Now all they talk about is being in a gang like you.
I'll do better.
Help me to the curb with this.
Where we going?
You're catching the bus back home.
We're picking up some things for Mrs. Jenkins.
Oh, ButterCream business. Did I ever tell you boys that my great-grandfather was one of the first ButterCreamers?
Yes, about a thou...

It was in the early days of the town after a raid killed many of the young men. The reverend asked some of the boys, including my great-grandfather, to help the widows by churning their cream into butter. It was hard work. The whole town started calling those boys the ButterCream Gang, and we've had one ever since. I've seen many come and go, but I think you boys are the best I've seen yet.
What's this?
It's a picture of a gang in Chicago. I'm doing an extra credit report on inner-city gangs.
Another report? Margaret, you already got an A. Why do you torture us?
They look pretty mean.
That's because they're a real gang, not like you guys.
I hope Pete doesn't run into them.
Wow, you look different.
So do you, man, but that's cool.
When did you get back?
Just now. Hey, how'd you guys even know I was in town?
We didn't.
We saw your grandfather yesterday, and he spaced out when we asked how you were doing.
We thought something might be wrong.
How come you didn't write?
Why, Pete Turner, I almost didn't recognize you!
Actually, I've changed my name to Pete Valdez. That was my mom's name.
Well, Pete Valdez, I can tell you've been to the big city.
I think Pete stole the treats he gave Lannie and Eldon and me from Mr. Graff's store. But Pete's my best friend in the world. I really missed him while he was gone.
I guess you think he joined a gang back in Chicago?
I don't know. But I don't want to get him into trouble. What should I do?

Son, if you think this pie was stolen, you need to either return it or pay for it. If you think Pete stole it, you need to tell Mr. Graff. But before you go accussing him, you need to find out the truth. You need to ask Pete.
I picked up a lot of bad habits back in Chicago. But hanging out with you's helping. It's helping a lot.
I heard Scott talking to Dad about Pete being in a gang, and I heard Pete say that he stole from Mr. Graff.
So that's why he wanted to borrow my report.
What should I do?
Well, what you need now is more proof of what Pete's been doing. Maybe some of your friends could help you follow him.
Why should we do that?
Because the ButterCream Gang can't do everything.

Pete's been picking on little kids, stealing from Mr. Graff, and Regina and her friends say they've seen him doing all sorts of different things. This is serious, Scott. I think you need to do something.
Well, what am I supposed to do?
Stand up to him. You're the only one he'll listen to.
Okay, I'll talk to him. See you, Margaret.
Not so fast. You still owe me that favor.
I thought talking to Pete was the favor.
No, that's just the right thing to do. The favor is you have to take me to the dance. Pick me up at seven and don't be late.
But...
Hey! Pick her up at seven and don't be late!
Pete, the ButterCreamers had a meeting. If you don't start doing your share of the work, you're out.
Okay, I make it unanimous. There, I'm out.
Don't you want to talk about it?

Smarten up! This is my gang now! I don't want anything to do with your stupid club! Me and these guys, we can have anything we want just by taking it, so you, your geek girlfriend, and everybody else just better stay out of my way!
Look, if you don't want to go to the dance with me, that's fine! I don't want you to feel obligated!
No, I really want to go to the dance with you.
You do? Why?
Well, I've never seen you look so pretty before.
You and your two buddies over there better watch out!
No, you watch out!
I'm warning you!
You best stop what you're doing!
Who's gonna stop me? You and the two stooges? I don't think so.
If we have to.
Oh, big talk, Scott. I'm real scared.
Yeah, well, this time it's not talk.
Are you threatening me? Is that a threat?
No, that's a promise.
I came here to fight.
I think there's a better way.
Sounds to me like an excuse not to fight.
I'm here, aren't I? I'm not afraid of you.
Yeah, well, maybe you should be. I learned a lot back there in Chicago.
Maybe not enough.
What's that supposed to mean?
What you learned in Chicago is how to fight.
What else is there?
Courage.
I ain't afraid of nothing.
All right, then, I challenge you to spend the whole day with me tomorrow, just like we did last summer. If you've got the guts.
Well, you did it again.
What'd I do now?
Made me relax and forget all my worries.
What worries?
Our big championship game tomorrow. I completely forgot about it.
Except it's not like old times, is it?
It could be.
I don't think so.
Why not?
Because things change. People change.
They don't have to.
They already have.
But look at you and me now. It's just like old times, isn't it?
Except that what you're really trying to do is safe me from myself, and I already know it's too late.
It is not. Today proves it.
No, the only thing today proves is that we *were* friends.
What do you mean?
Sometimes I want so bad for things to be the way they were! But they can't!
But why not?

They can't! It's like you're riding your bike somewhere, and you get lost. You try to go back and figure out where you made the wrong turn, but you don't know where you made the wrong turn, and every turn you make just gets you more and more lost.
You never once asked me what happened to me in Chicago! You never once asked me!
What's going on? What happened?
It's about Pete.
I got a letter from his aunt today.
I just want you to know, son, it doesn't always turn out this way.
What happened?
I'm really proud of you. You did the right thing.
Will someone please tell me what's going on?
Mr. Turner, I think we ought to have the reverend read that letter.

[reading]
"Dear Mr. Turner, I know I haven't written since last year when I told you that Pete was coming back to town to stay for the summer. I was reading the paper today when I saw his name in the article included. I guess it's pretty self-explanatory." Scott, why don't you read this?

[reading]
"Today at two o'clock, the mayor of Chicago honored, for the first time in the city's history, a member of a gang. That gang member was Pete Turner. Mr. Turner's gang is rather unusual. Mr. Turner tells his gang, 'If you accept yourself for who you are and truly love others, a lot of good will happen.' This gang, which only a few months ago was typical of those found in the area, refuses to fight or participate in any illegal activities and instead devotes much of their time to helping and serving the community around them."

Will we really take the time to learn to love all people? Not just our friends, but our enemies and those who hurt and abuse us? We simply cannot just offer our help and love and friendship to those people when it's convenient for us. The old Mosaic law of an eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth has been replaced. It's been replaced by the concept of turning the other cheek. Will we do it with cheerful hearts?

Someone did a golden deed. They willfully said, "I'm glad to give". And cheerfully tried to lift a load. Was that somebody you.. was that somebody you? Is our spiritual progression based on our ability to love and care for one another? I think we'd all admit that there is a direct correlation between our ability to love and care for one another, and the quality of our own lives. But to what degree do those abilities effect the quality of the lives of those around us? Will we really take the time to learn to love all, not just our friends, but our enemies? Those who hurt and misuse us. We simply cannot offer our help, love and friendship to people when it's convenient. The old mosaic law of, "An eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth" has been replaced. It's been replaced by the concept of turning the other cheek. And will we do it with a cheerful heart, regardless of whether or not there's a reward in it for us? Because I can tell you this; Whether or not you see the results of your actions, they do make a difference. And absolutely no good deed goes unrewarded.
Just remember, in my neck of the woods, there are only two kinds of people, your friends and your enemies.
Is that a threat?
No, that's a promise.
I'm sorry, Scott, I wish there was something I could do with him.
You could send him back to Chicago where he belongs!
Did you know that India was still ruled by England until after World War Two?
No, Coach, I didn't know that.

They tried to win their independence through violence over the years, but they never quite succeeded. Don't swing too early, wait for the ball. Finally a man by the name of Mahatma Gandhi convinced the people that they could win their independence without using violence. A lot of people thought he was crazy, but it turned out he was right. When somebody asked him why he was so sure that nonviolence would work, he said that the idea of an eye for an eye only made the whole world blind.
Absolutely no good deed goes unrewarded.
Shouldn't doing what's right change something?

Scott, you know I don't like to talk much about the war, but in Vietnam, I knew a soldier who always introduced himself by saying, 'Hi, I'm Scott Paulsen, and I'm a Christian.' Well, needless to say, we made his life miserable because of what he believed, but he never got angry at us. In fact, he was always the first one to help whenever anyone needed anything. I tried to get him to talk about it one night, but all he would say was, 'Tom, the way you treat me is between you and your god. The way I treat you is between me and mine.' Well, a few months later, Private Paulsen was killed. We were out on night patrol, and we got ambused. Twenty men down. Private Paulsen, being the man that he was, had volunteered to go, and the ironic thing about the situation was that he died saving a soldier who absolutely hated him. I just couldn't understand why he would do it. Then the war ended and life went on, and I forgot all about him until the night you were born. The first time I held you in my arms, I knew that I would give my life to protect you. And in that moment, I remembered Private Scott Paulsen.
Two papers in one day? You are an anteater, aren't you? To what do I owe this unexpected surprise?
Pete. My dad made it sound so easy in his story, but in real life, it's a lot harder.
Maybe it isn't supposed to be easy.
I wouldn't mind if it would make a difference, but Pete's just getting worse.
I know I should've told you sooner, but Pete's been stealing from your store. He had the nerve to tell me that you owed it to him for all the stuff's he done for you.
I thank you, Scott, for telling me. You're right, you should've me sooner, but if it makes you feel any better, I already knew.
You did? Why didn't you do anything about it?
I did. I thought about it, and I decided that a little love and patience was worth more than a few pennies.
But you shouldn't let him steal from you.
You're right. You're absolutely right. So from on, I'm just going to give him the treats, in appreciation of all the help he's given me. Then he won't be stealing.
I think somebody broke into Pete's house!
Are you sure?
No, but I left Eldon there to watch.
Eldon?
Could you see me sending him for help?
Well, that's a good point.
I promised him a big chocolate milkshake if he would just stay there.
We just saved you!
Saved me? What did you save me from? I set the whole thing up to get money to go back to Chicago!
I don't believe that! Why?
You ruined everything!
Give me your money, old man! Open it up, come on!
All right, Pete, if you need money, I'll give you some.
Don't you get it? You're being robbed here!
Well, I know that's what you're trying to do, Pete, but if I give you the money, then you're not robbing me. Here's two hundred and seventy-four dollars. Is that enough?
You're as crazy as Scott! This whole town's crazy!
You better back off, Scott, or I'm gonna swing you upside the head! You're not gonna touch me!

You're right, I'm not. I just want to know what you really want. I've done everything I know to show that I accept you for who you are. You're my friend no matter what you do. I've tried to show you that. Pete, what do you really want?
I want you to hate me!
Hate you? Why?
Because I hate myself!
Guys, I've been thinking.
About what?
Well, now there's a Chicago chapter of the ButterCream Gang.
Yeah, so?
I think it's cool.
But there's another change the ButterCreamers need to make.
And what's that?
I think it's time for the ButterCream Gang to have a girl member.
[repeated line]
You got the right one, baby!
You turned out to be so selfish.
What makes you think I'm being selfish?
You take things, and you only think of yourself.

I only take what I deserve! I spent hours helping people like Mr. Graff and never got anything in return. I've done plenty for this crummy little town, and what did I get for it? Nothing! No, Scott, I think you're the one being selfish!
Me?
Yeah, you! Real friends accept each other for who they are, but you're only willing to be my friend if I change. I'm not who I was, Scott, I am who I am!
That's garbage! You chose who you are! I'm trying to be your friend, so don't accuse me of being selfish!
